column1: Suphan Buri (Thai: สุพรรณบุรี
column2: pronounced [sù.pʰān būrīː]) is one of Thailand's seventy-six provinces (changwat) of central Thailand. Neighbouring provinces are (from north clockwise) Uthai Thani

column1: The word suphan originates from the Sanskrit word Suvarna (Devanagari: सुवर्ण)
column3: and the word buri from Sanskrit purī (Devanagari: पुरी)
column4: meaning 'town' or 'city'. Hence the name of the province literally means 'city of gold'.

column1: The terrain of the province is mostly low river plains
column2: with small mountain ranges in the north and the west of the province. The southeastern part with the very low plain of the Tha Chin River is paddy rice farming area.

column1: Suphan Buri might be the site of the legendary Suvarnabhumi
column2: which is mentioned in very old Buddhist writings. However the first confirmed historical settlement was in the Dvaravati period
column3: when the city was known as Meuang Thawarawadi Si Suphannaphumi ('the Dvaravati city of Suvarnabhumi'). Its founding took place c. 877-882. Later it was called U Thong
column4: and was the home city of Prince U Thong
column5: the founder of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. King Khun Luang Pha Ngua gave it the current name. Suphan Buri was a border city
column6: and the site of several battles with the neighbouring Burmese.

column1: The province is Thailand's largest producer of water chestnuts (Thai: ลูกแห้ว
column3: grown mainly in Mueang Suphan Buri
column5: and the Si Prachan Districts of the province. About half of the province's 3
column6: 000 rai of cultivated water chestnuts are found in Tambon Wang Yang of Si Prachan. The vegetable was registered as a geographical indication (GI) product of Suphan Buri in 2017. The Thai dessert thapthim krop (Thai: ทับทิมกรอบ)
column7: with water chestnuts as its main ingredient
column8: was named one of the world's best 50 desserts in 2019 by CNN Travel.

column1: The provincial seal shows the elephant battle between King Naresuan the Great and the crown prince of Burma in 1592
column2: which took place in Suphan Buri.

column1: The provincial tree is the ebony tree (Diospyros mollis)
The province is divided into 10 districts (amphoes). The districts are further divided into 110 subdistricts (tambons) and 977 villages (mubans).

As of 26 November 2019 there are: one Suphan Buri Provincial Administration Organisation (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and 45 municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Suphan Buri and Song Phi Nong have town (thesaban mueang) status. Further 43 subdistrict municipalities (thesaban tambon). The non-municipal areas are administered by 81 Subdistrict Administrative Organisations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).
Suphan Buri's main hospital is Chao Phraya Yommarat Hospital
column2: operated by the Ministry of Public Health.

column2: officially terminating at Suphan Buri Railway Station. The branch meets the main line at Nong Pladuk Junction near Ban Pong.
